content:
Posted: April 6, 2014
												This game, believe it or not, is a decade old.  Even with that considered, it still looks pretty decent to this day.  I highly recommend this game over the new BFG version for a number of reasons both subjective and objective.The objective reason is obvious, that being that sikk mod (may be wrong spelling), along with the wolfsomething texture pack make it look even better than the BFG edition.   The rest is subjective.  I have heard and seen play throughs of the new lost mission in the BFG edition.  Not only does it make no sense along the lines of Aliens Colonial Marines with Michael Bean still being alive, but the levels are not very compelling.Overall if you can get the origional with the classic flashlight with no gun I suggest playing this game on hard, without the ducktape mod.  The game was designed with this as a game mechanic even though, from what I have heard it was a technical compromise.  One interesting thing about the new BFG version with the suit flashlight is that there are no shadows.  Where as with the hand held flashlight there are.  Carmack evidently wanted flashlight design to go in one direction while the industry took another.  This is why for those of you who played quake 4, using the same engine, you can see your allied NPcs flashlights, but in left 4 dead you cannot.  Back to the game and less about tech history. This game has good graphics even without mods.  It was one of those games that when it came out was hands down the best looking thing out on the market.  If your keen about moding, I mentioned a really good texture pack above.  The game has a nice variety of enemies and guns.  This is a game back in the days where you did not need 10 smgs, 10 asault rifles, and so on.  You get your standard shotgun, machine gun, plasma gun, and BFG!!!  Despite people calling most enemies idiots you will die a few times on hard so save often.  There is some strategy such as with the tentecal commando.  Knowing to let him run up to you and duck, shoot, stand, shoot in the face is a hard but excellent tactic. (timing wise you can mess up and die real fast)  Also start the game on hard.  Any horror game (im not saying this is survival horror, but it applies to that as well) should in my humble opinion be played on the hardest difficulty available, in the dark, and with a headset.  As scary as the artwork or demonic base can get, its not very scary if your enemies are a joke.  Since there is no regenerating health you will find yourself with 32 hp on many occasions, one hit away from death from a hard ememy.  Thats tension baby!Also while this is entirely up to you, I must say playing with the basic flashlight design really makes or breaks the game for me.  Having played it with both, I cannot stress how there is worse lighting and less tension.  Yes I know a flashlight is one of the basic attachments to any gun and it makes no sense, but we are playing a game about demons from hell.  The flashlight leaves you vulnerable and makes you slowly explore rooms until hell breaks loose.  Also slowing down allows you to hear enemies hiding.  Ive often used the tactic of fill the room with grenades and then enter (Careful those things love to blow you up).  The game does have monster closets, and while cheap, they do scare you and I honestly hated them in 2004, but really came to like them when I replayed recently.  In the end its your choice about the flashlight, just know it will change the game experience.Multiplayer is dead so your getting this for the singleplayer.  Overall its a nice scary walk through time.  Hope this was helpful, if not let me know why so I can improve.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2013
												DOOM 3 is a serviceable 2004 horror shooter that just happens to be a Doom game, for better and worse. It's not on the level of its forebears, but it's not terrible either. At the very least, download Killatomate's Realistic Weapons mod to make your firepower not garbage. Avoid the BFG Edition - it screws with gameplay balance, and is incompatible with mods, of which there's plenty to make OG look even better than BFG. (I didn't like the BFG ports of classic Doom either: they modify the games too much and run poorly.)So hey, this is still Doom, right? There's too much ammo and health lying around to really qualify Doom 3 as survival horror, so it must be. While I think the game could absolutely have used more open spaces, I don't mind the game mainly taking place in linear corridors because they are very good corridors.Lot of PDAs lying around to collect though, and only like two or three female characters in the entire game, so you know this is a 2004 product. The PDAs at least give the game an air of immersion and worldbuilding. It's a shame the game as linear as it is, since a branching plot point (an actual one) would have been a good gameplay point, not to mention a bit of a callback to the classics' level design.The aforementioned mod makes the guns actually fun to use instead of wet cardboard, to the point where I consider it a requirement since you happen to spend a lot of the game using them on the demons. Some of the guns still become superfluous after a while, since there's more of them here than in the original games. When you have a rocket launcher and grenades and a chaingun and an SMG, you tend to use what you feel like using. Meanwhile, the bigger problem with Doom 3's gameplay is that every other encounter is a cheap 'gotcha' or some sort of monster closet, most of which get predictable after a while. The originals did this too, but not nearly as much nor as egregiously.There's also a number of encounters with multiple little spider enemies crawling out of vents and such where all you do is just stand there and shoot them, which gets a little tedious. System Shock had respawning enemies, which would have been an interesting experiment with the Doom formula here and at the very least less annoying than a dozen spiders crawling one at a time out of a vent shaft.Don't get me wrong, this game builds enough tension that it can get away with jumpscares every so often, and it's not like they're the obnoxious full-screen "find the hidden object" type, but Silent Hill this ain't. While I would argue Doom 3 actually pulls off its horror much better than it does its terror, that doesn't excuse the entirely scripted monster closets getting old after a while. The lack of checkpoints means that if you're caught off-guard by one, you potentially get to replay the entire level as well.Doom 3's story is...well, it exists. For the most part, it doesn't detract from the game. You might wonder what Doom is doing with such an overt story, but really, iD couldn't not write one in 2004. Games had come a long way since 1993, and writing in games at the time was just starting to become more than a vestigial element. Of course, Doom 3 also came before the time when some people realized that while not every game needs a thin layer of contrived plot, games as a whole need good writing.In comparison, MachineGames' 2014 game Wolfenstein: The New Order (a continuation of iD's only shooter franchise older than Doom) has writing that adds to the game, and meanwhile the 2016 Doom reboot does a lot more than Doom 3 with less than what 3 has.Anyway. One of the two main problems here are the lack of sound effects in the audio logs, a problem I'll mention the System Shock games didn't have. The other is the fact that Dr. Betruger is by far the most corny, hokey, Snidely Whiplash-evil character in any FPS ever, and that's REALLY saying something.I don't even need to spoil the fact that he's evil because you see it coming from a mile away the moment you first see him. His name is literally German for 'betrayal'. He veers between creepy and funny nearly every time you hear him say you're DOOOOOMED!!! MUAHAHAHA!!! He's the one vestigal element Doom 3 would have been almost entirely better off without.This game was honestly never going to live up to the originals. Mainly because the originals were much more progressive and envelope-pushing at exactly the right time, and were much more flexible to boot, but also because they were products of the late stage of videogaming's 'childhood'.Doom 3, on the other hand, is a product of video gaming's adolescent period. It trades those gracefully aging MIDI riffs and pixels for surplus buckets of grimness and horror, a look that while probably very fluid and good for 2004, doesn't hold up that well today without mods. It's worth mentioning though that the game's code is very well-written, and that the most taxing element for 2004 PCs - the dynamic lighting engine - is still fairly impressive.Both of those accomplishments come with a caveat, however, in that the whole game could frankly be summed up as a long-form tech demo for the developers' id Tech 4 engine, which they later leased out to other developers. I will, at least, praise the interactive computer interfaces as being truly excellent and something I'd like to see more of today.Ultimately, if you're willing to put a little modding work into it and deal with the fact that, taking everything into account, this game is both lesser than and has aged more than the originals in its series, you will find a decent game.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2013
												So Steam Roulette selected DOOM3 to be game #2 of this year's Steam Backlog Blitz. At first I was kinda excited as I hadn't really touched DOOM3 since I bought x amount of years ago. I was recommended to download and use the sikkmod, which I too would recommend. Provides some nicely updated graphics and options to play around with. First thing I will say about this game is that it's long. Certainly long for a FPS, even more so compared to modern standards. You'll easily be playing this game for 12+ hours, which could be a good or a bad thing depending on what you like from a FPS. I personally found it a little too long, and according to Steam it took me 19 hours to finish this... It's a very slow paced game, which is odd for a DOOM title. Some might like that, but if you've grown up with DOOM and even DOOM II then it's a strange experience. They could easily have dropped a level or two from the middle of the game, or even had more 'traditional DOOM' levels as replacements. However, the slow pace of the game is highlighted nicely by the lighting and the sound within the game. I know some people didn't like the torch/weapon swapping, but I found it increased the level of tension within the game (however I did find it led to an increased level of bordem at times). Yet, the cheap scares and the over use of the one scare tactic do become tiresome very quickly. Overall it was an OK experience, if a little too long and not as frantic as I expected. Graphics, lighting and atmosphere are still good today as they would have been back in 2004. So credit must go to ID for that. If you play this in bitesized chunks you'll probably avoid the feeling of the game dragging on.If you see this cheap in the sales, have a good pair of headphones, and turn the lights off... you're in for a decent experience.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
												This is a great game to play even if it doesn't stick to the original DOOM and DOOM 2 game. I had fun shooting and blowing up spawns of satin while experiencing some of the jumpscares DOOM 3 had to offer. Having access to every weapon instead of limiting it to two is always fun to expierece because the more the marrier. Weapon progression in this game is enjoyable making players start form a lonely pistol to a BFG that kills everything in front of you because BIG F****** GUN! thats why. The plot is not simplified like the earlier titles but is still good and allows players to make a choice, a small one at that, to  send out a distress beacan or not . This choice is very minor and only effects the cutscene at the end making replaying the game for that choice not a big priority. The end boss battle feels a bit underwelming though as the player does nothing but run in a circle and wait for an item to charge up just to use it on the boss repeatedly. Finding PDA's for lore and locker codes is a great implimentation because it makes players search around the area if they want the goodies locked in that locker. Enemy variasion is good making players change tactics to tackle certain foes and introducing them is good as well. Replaying the game to have fun or experience a harder difficulty is fun and enjoyable as the game itself I feel can be played multiple times and still be fun. I recommend playing this game with sikkmod as it makes a game from 2003 look not only good but play better and smoother. Playing this game without sikkmod is okay too but the player will have to moddify the game anyway as the in game settings dosen't support 1920 by 1080p resolution. Information on the sikkmod modification and resoulution fix can be found in the forums.

												Well although it's not as good as the first two games in series, Doom 3 is an awesome game. Its atmosphere is quite like in the older games, but with the new flashlight thing going on. Some people didn't like this feature, but for me, it was a good way to scare theâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥out of me back when I first played it. The graphics were awesome back then and I still think they're gorgeous even on today's standards. The sound effects could be a little more "brutal". For exemple, the monster noises/ roars didn't sound like something that came directly from a hell portal, as the imp and hell knight's roar on Doom. Also the weapons didn't pack the punch like the chaingun or the shotgun on the older games. The shotgun shot noises just sound like an toy gun. And the gameplay although it's meant to be arcade like its predecessors, sometimes its dull. There are certain parts where monsters spawn exactly on the same place and if you die, you can just memorize when it'll come out and before the monster appears, you can just start to shoot on the spot to easily kill the monster.Aside from those little things, some small bugs and minor gameplay issues, I'd totally recommend it. Worth the time spent, I finished this game about 4-5 times or more. Also check for the hi-res modes on google, they're better than the BFG version.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2016
												The original overrated monster closet game.Doom 3 has been widely hailed as one of the scariest games ever made, presumably by the sort of people who think all it takes to file a movie under the horror genre is the presence of a monster and maybe turning a few lights off. Doom 3 is little more than Baby's First Dead Space, and while that's a little bit unfair as it obviously came well before its most obvious imitator, it isn't even remotely scary and is barely passable as a shooter.Let me start by approaching the horror half the of the equation: the primary emotion that horror feeds on is fear. Fear stems from vulnerability. Now, how can one possibly feel vulnerable while packing more firepower than a Texan wedding, up to and including two different instant-kill weapons? By far the most reliably lethal thing in the game was the bloody level design, between its clumsy platforming and occasionally â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥t set design (Oh, you shot this fragile glass fuel pipe in the midst of a close-quarters firefight? Enjoy instant vaporization, sucker). Meanwhile, the atmosphere the game attempted to set up was about as scary as Halloween decorations, so if you have a phobia of red color filters and balding middle-aged men laughing at you over the intercom, I suppose you might get a few frights out of it.As for the shooting... it's just not Doom. Every Doom game before or since has been high-octane shooty-bang action characterized by constant movement and overwhelming firepower on both sides. What it is NOT, is clomping down tight corridors with all the lights off fighting half a dozen enemies at a time - tops - while the lackluster sound design robs you of any situational awareness so the game can 'scare' you with some zombie twatbasket smacking you on the back of your head because somehow a trained marine can't pick up on an obese corpse shambling up behind him on noisy grate floors.I haven't played the Resurrection of Evil expansion yet, but I'll review that seperately when I do. As for Doom 3 itself, I'd rather just play Dead Space again. Or that System Shock remake, when that comes out.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												Doom 3 is slower-paced than Doom 2; has worse level design than Doom 2; is less immersive than Doom 2 (stop pulling the camera away from first-person you â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥); has messy convoluted objectives whereas Doom 2 had the perfectly substantial 'find the exit'. Also, why the hell did they give the protagonist such an irritating voice, or one at all for that matter?Having said that, I was pleasantly surprised by Doom 3. I was expecting it to be worse than the classic Doom games that we're all so fond of -- and in the aforementioned ways it certainly is -- but overall it turned out to simply be different to them.The old formula is still here: get from A to B, shoot the monsters between you and B, pick up armour, health and ammo along the way. The gameplay hasn't been changed into dull survival horror or cover-based shooting or anything modern and awful like that. It's just been slowed down a tad and made a bit scarier and more realistic, and for many people that'll definitely be a good thing. On top of that, Doom 3 obviously has far better visuals than the old games in both realism and artistic prowess. Pretty demons are always more fun to shoot than ugly ones.So even if you love Dooms 1 & 2 and are terrified of change, I'd say there's a good chance you'll still love the shiny latest addition to the family. You just won't love it for quite the same reasons.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												It was really hard for me to recommend this game initially. I had played 5-6 levels and I was getting increasingly frustrated with the game. It felt nothing like Doom, and worse still it didn't feel fun at all. Read on and I'll tell you why you should get this game anyway.First off: This game is old. It runs by default in 4:3 resolution. You can find several solutions to this in the forums.Doom 3 tries really hard to be FEAR, Half-Life and Doom all at the same time. It takes a more realistic, dark and gritty approach to the original Doom storyline. It replaces frantic gun-blazing and monsterspamming with dark, gloomy and "scary" corridors with fewer, more powerful enemies. This in itself is not a bad thing. After all, Half-Life was a great game!The narrative is mostly told through voice overs or found PDAs. I kinda like this approach, it keeps you inside the world. Where this game suffers really badly is the actual gameplay. It tries really hard to be scary and it shows. It's pretentious at best and ham-fisted at worst when it comes to the so called "scary moments" with color shifts, lights going out and comically overplayed "evil laughs" echoing through the halls. The guns feel like pellet guns. There is no punch to any of the weapons, the sound assets for them are extremely weak and there is no satisfying feel to any of the weapons when you fire them. Enemies feel bullet-spongy and have a really annoying habit of not being present in the game world until you pass a certain trigger. This leads to excessively annoying moments where enemies keep coming from areas that you have already cleared. It's almost every single time you encounter enemies you'll have some coming from behind you. This can be cool for some panic induced fighting on occasion, but this game does it every single time and it gets old FAST.Now, with all these problems, why do I recommend it? Because I got fed up and installed Doom 3 XTRA mod. This mod updates graphics, model assets, textures and sounds to a more modern standard, but it also fixes all the problems I have with the gameplay. By giving weapons more punch and over all more satisfying oomph and sounds, it makes the shooting fun again. Sure the game is still overly pretentious with its scary "jack in a box" moments and enemies always coming from behind, but you know what? With Doom 3 XTRA I don't give a â¥â¥â¥â¥. Thar be demons to shoot in the face!So in short, if you intend to get this game don't even bother with the stock game. Doom 3 XTRA turns this game from a boring yawnfest into a frantic shooter with some ignorable issues.

Posted: November 28, 2015
												Doom 3 is a damn fine shooter! I have no idea why people are so split about this game.Pros:+ Great graphics (especially at the time) and amazing lighting. (And even better with sikkmod)+ Incredible level design, it's really hard to get lost in these levels.+ Pretty good voice acting.+ Entertaining story.+ Quite a long campaign (8-10 hours).+ Great mix of horror and action.Neutral:+- You have to switch back and forth between your flashlight and you weapons. This can be immersive or annoying depending on the person.+- The game gives you a ridiculous amount of ammo, therefore not really bringing in a sense of tension. I have seen other people mention that ammo is sparse, but one must require an impressively itchy trigger-finger in order to run dry. I mean honestly, I can't recall a single moment I had less than 200 shotgun shells at my disposal.Cons:- Cheap enemy placements. You will frequently run into imps that pounce at you placed behind doors, that gain aimbot abilities, and can turn 90 degrees around corners. Unless you have godlike reactions, this will hurt you, and maybe kill you. A lot.- Can get a little repetetive, both in gameplay and locations.- The weapons are a little wierdly implemented. The pistol and your fists are basically useless after the first 15 minutes, and your shotgun's range is so hilariously bad, it's basically a meleeweapon. I reccomend downloading the realistic weapons mod to fix some of these weird design choices. : http://www.moddb.com/mods/realistic-weapons/downloads/doom-3-realistic-weapons-v10A great action- adventure game you can get for dirt cheap. Absolutely reccomended. 8/10

content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
THIS GAME SCORES [0 1 | 2 *3*] = ~88% (75%-100%)Doom 3 (published 2004) is an awesome hellish corridor shooter with a great (albeit simple) campaign story, if you please ignore that demons from Hell should be unimpressed by earthly firepower.It's a very immersive ride that I have taken from A to Z at least 4 times. If you want to forget the world and live through a demonic science fiction story, Doom 3 is the way to go.The sounds require a bit of getting used to because they are equalized / dynamic compressed too extremely (though not as insanely as in Bioshock Infinite), but after a while this will feel alright.People say that Doom 3 is visually too dark, but what they are missing is that this is a game for serious gamers who want to go on an immersive ride instead of just having fun in the living room with friends. So, turn off the lights, use a big screen, tweak the FOV (The console allows to set anything you want.), and get lost for 12-18 hours in a dark science fiction tale that, while kind of routine once you know how to handle your weapons, will keep you on the edge throughout.Some people don't like that it takes a while before the action starts. Those, too, are not serious gamers. Drink up the mood! Role-play! Explore this science fiction reality while you're not yet under pressure and while things are still well lit.TECHDoom 3 uses real-time lighting throughout, and I believe it was even the first 3D 1st person campaign shooter that did this. While this has visual downsides (especially since the engine is old, so there is no hint of Global Illumination) compared to baked light-maps, it contributes immensely to the experience, and they show it off in quite a few places. Try to imagine what it's like to see this for the first time. Oooh! Aaah! Who wants to touch me.Both Doom 3 and the BFG edition can be modded, but not all D3 mods work with D3BFG. I played through the unchanged version of both and enjoyed both. I copy&pasted this review text to both.The Doom 3 title music is mono and very badly equalized - sounds like complete crap. Yay, a DVD-sized game, and they saved 2 MB on the title track. :( And guess what they did not change when they created the BFG edition - yep, as unfathomable as it may seem, the crappy title music file. In Doom 3 (Non-BFG.), you could at least easily mod the title music by supplying a file (incl. path) of the same name as it was in the data archive files, so I obtained a better sounding (and stereo) version of the track and even equalized it for more boom. Well, apart from this drastic oversight, Doom 3 is a great product.

Enemies feel bullet-spongy and have a really annoying habit of not being present in the game world until you pass a certain trigger. This leads to excessively annoying moments where enemies keep coming from areas that you have already cleared. It's almost every single time you encounter enemies you'll have some coming from behind you. This can be cool for some panic induced fighting on occasion, but this game does it every single time and it gets old FAST.Now, with all these problems, why do I recommend it? Because I got fed up and installed Doom 3 XTRA mod. This mod updates graphics, model assets, textures and sounds to a more modern standard, but it also fixes all the problems I have with the gameplay. By giving weapons more punch and over all more satisfying oomph and sounds, it makes the shooting fun again. Sure the game is still overly pretentious with its scary "jack in a box" moments and enemies always coming from behind, but you know what? With Doom 3 XTRA I don't give a â¥â¥â¥â¥. Thar be demons to shoot in the face!So in short, if you intend to get this game don't even bother with the stock game. Doom 3 XTRA turns this game from a boring yawnfest into a frantic shooter with some ignorable issues.

												tl:dr it's like half-life, but on mars. the game feels more frustrating than it should be (on hard difficulty) not sure if it's hit detection or what, but most of my damage output felt inoncistent. sometimes i would 1 shot imps with a shotgun and sometimes i'd empty entire magezines to no avail. the enemy ai is rock stupid consisting of only charging your position be it with guns, hellfire, w/e, and any hitscan weapons they use are nearly 100% accurate so there's no chance you'll be dodging anything that isn't a projectile. however, the enemy types are extremely varied and numerous which forces you to pick the right weapon for the situation. every encounter feels like a pop quiz of "which weapon is most effective against this enemy" and i think this is where the enjoyment can be found. i never felt like i was killed from something unfair becuase if you pick the right weapon for the right enemy, you can survive anything.the campaign was much longer than i expected and it was for the most part a logical progression. the character you play known only as "the marine" is your standard emotionless silent protagonist who is transferred the a mars base as security. your day starts off normal until you walk for a while and everything goes batsh*t crazy. (sound familair?) when the game finally picks up you're constantly being barked at to move faster by your CO who apparenly isn't dealing with the limitless demons that you are because he has plenty of time to tell you to pick up the pace.the game isn't terrible by any means, but it has very little personalty to it.  nameless marine fights nameless demons who are being controlled by obvious badguy. i'd suggest picking this up on sale, but other than that, it's not worth full price

content:

												It's dark. It's heavily scripted. There are jump scares. You will learn to anticipate them and track enemies in the dark and then it won't be that scary. In fact, you'll probably be frustrated more than anything else, especially if you don't quicksave. At the end of the day though, it's a good, filling experience, well worth the purchase. Once you get the bigger weapons towards the end of the campaign it almost feels like Painkiller, just with more mundane weapons. Except for one of them, but you can figure that out yourself.AFAIK the multiplayer is dead, so you should only buy this if you're interested in between 10-15 hours (20 if it's your first time playing and you keep dying to surprises like I did) of timeless single-player FPS action, roughly four parts shooting to one part clicking on buttons and one part awkwardly fumbling around with the flashlight.

												tl:dr it's like half-life, but on mars. the game feels more frustrating than it should be (on hard difficulty) not sure if it's hit detection or what, but most of my damage output felt inoncistent. sometimes i would 1 shot imps with a shotgun and sometimes i'd empty entire magezines to no avail. the enemy ai is rock stupid consisting of only charging your position be it with guns, hellfire, w/e, and any hitscan weapons they use are nearly 100% accurate so there's no chance you'll be dodging anything that isn't a projectile. however, the enemy types are extremely varied and numerous which forces you to pick the right weapon for the situation. every encounter feels like a pop quiz of "which weapon is most effective against this enemy" and i think this is where the enjoyment can be found. i never felt like i was killed from something unfair becuase if you pick the right weapon for the right enemy, you can survive anything.the campaign was much longer than i expected and it was for the most part a logical progression. the character you play known only as "the marine" is your standard emotionless silent protagonist who is transferred the a mars base as security. your day starts off normal until you walk for a while and everything goes batsh*t crazy. (sound familair?) when the game finally picks up you're constantly being barked at to move faster by your CO who apparenly isn't dealing with the limitless demons that you are because he has plenty of time to tell you to pick up the pace.the game isn't terrible by any means, but it has very little personalty to it.  nameless marine fights nameless demons who are being controlled by obvious badguy. i'd suggest picking this up on sale, but other than that, it's not worth full price

Posted: October 8, 2016
												It's dark. It's heavily scripted. There are jump scares. You will learn to anticipate them and track enemies in the dark and then it won't be that scary. In fact, you'll probably be frustrated more than anything else, especially if you don't quicksave. At the end of the day though, it's a good, filling experience, well worth the purchase. Once you get the bigger weapons towards the end of the campaign it almost feels like Painkiller, just with more mundane weapons. Except for one of them, but you can figure that out yourself.AFAIK the multiplayer is dead, so you should only buy this if you're interested in between 10-15 hours (20 if it's your first time playing and you keep dying to surprises like I did) of timeless single-player FPS action, roughly four parts shooting to one part clicking on buttons and one part awkwardly fumbling around with the flashlight.

Posted: March 7, 2016
												In its original form (ie without mods) Doom 3 is incredibly bland and unsatisfying. I tried to like it for so long because the graphics, at the time, were basically unmatched, like the Doom titles before it. But even as a young lad back in the early 2000s this game was way too boring for me. The combat itself felt incredibly flat even compared to the original Doom games. Enemy bodies disappear before they even hit the ground. The guns sound likeâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ The level design may have gone over well in the mid to late 90s but by the time this game came out it felt anachronistically bland - basically just long metal corridor after long metal corridor. Say what you want about Halo 1's level design, at least you'd go outside and have a change of scenery every once in a while. In this game, all you do is plod around and shoot at enemies with your clunky Mattel toy gun and watch as the enemies disappear before you have a chance to see the ragdoll physics, set in a universe where light only comes in two forms -  brighter than the sun or darker than space. I suspect alot of people are projecting their love of the series as a whole onto this game individually when they praise it.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
												--- DOOM 3 ---The good stuff...- Good graphics with audio in world class.- Tight controls.- Scary as hell - DOOM 3 relay on audio/music to be scary and keep the player on edge at all times, just like any good horror movie - play it alone in the middle of the night with the volume cranked. Bring extra underwear.- ID's attention to details are amazing as usual.- The game has been nicely balanced and offer a challenge, even if you are good at shooters.The bad stuff...- A little too much emphasis on horror and lacks somewhat in the action department - it should be the other way around like the old-school DOOM games.- Even if the environments are beautifully crafted they do get old - pretty quick. It's tight, it's dark, there are long hallways with at least one jump scare somewhere..... and rinse and repeat. Final verdict...8/10 - just buy the game - it's DOOM and it's good.

Posted: October 4, 2016
												!!Important note!!If you don't own doom and doom 2, you will probably better off buying the Doom BFG edition. with that you get doom 3, resurrection, doom and doom 2,  you also get the lost mission expansion pack which is an exclusive expansion pack for the BFG edition and you also get an extra episode for doom 2 called no rest for the living. Doom and Doom 2 can also be played on the GZdoom source port as well. Just remember to check the system requirements for the BFG edition because they are much more demanding compared to the original doom 3 and resurrection games. The BFG edition doesn't have finale doom or the master levels.      What I liked about the gameâ¢	Fantastic level design, I liked the industrial/science setting of the game. I liked seeing all of the machines in the environment working and all of the computers showing lots of information.â¢	Interesting story on how the demon invasion happened. â¢	The game has a good horror atmosphere, there are also some jump scares and unexpected moments, it's not up there with fear or condemned but it's still good. â¢	Plenty of secrets to be found, some are hidden in quite clever places. With some of the secrets, you have to interact with the in-game computer to find them. You can find PDA'S of other workers at the UAC, which tells you what there work role, was. The PDA'S also contain audio logs, emails and also give you security clearances. You can also find video disks, which have information on them about certain things.  â¢	An awesome selection of firearms. My favourite weapons in the game were the machinegun and the plasma gun. â¢	Lots of different enemies to kill. Most of the enemies in doom and doom2 are in this game (IMP, Pinkie, Commando, and the lost souls); there are also some new enemies as well. Amazing boss fights, especially the 2nd boss fight and the last. Brilliant antagonist, Dr Malcolm Betruger.  â¢	 I know some people won't agree with this but, I quite liked the changes they made to doom 3, like making it slower paced, concentrating more on the horror experience and concentrating more on the story. It was something new and after playing doom, doom 2, finale, and master, I don't think I would enjoyed it as much if the game play in doom 3 was the same as the previous games. That's my opinion anyway.â¢	I prefer this version over  the BFG edition. I like how you have to equip the flashlight and you don't have to turn it off to let it recharge. I would say this version is much challenging. I found that certain types of ammo in this version were much scarcer.   â¢Awesome music theme.What I disliked or was disappointed withâ¢	No Baron Of Hell â¢	The death animations aren't very good, the demons just frizzle up. â¢	The character you play as doesn't look very badass. The character in resurrection of evil looks much better. â¢ I wish the game could autosave more often.   ConclusionOne of my all time favourite games. If you liked Quake 4, Prey or Fear I highly recommend you buy this game. 95/100

Not the DOOM 3 We were Hoping ForWell.. this is a hardone. I normally start these out with something along the lines of: "If you liked X you'll like this game.", but for the life of me I can't think of a game close enough to this to liken it to.  I certainlty Can't say: "If you liked Doom or Doom 2 , you'll love this game.", because the game takes a sharp departure in aesthetics, play-style and ... AH-HA! Dead Space. If you liked Dead Space you... er, never mind. That's just it, the game feels like iot was the victim of schizophranic development. GOne now are the fast-paced, cirlcle-strafing, Shotgun-Blasting, Demon-Splattering game we remember from Doom 2. Now replaced by dark, Claustrophobic,  corridors and cheap jumpscares.Doom3 tries to be somewhere Between Dead Space and System Shock 2 and manages to be neither.  Now credit where credit is due. The game looks gorgeous and atmospheric., when you can actuially see anything. THe Mars base actually feels like the sort of place people work and live in.  However this sort of upsets the game flow and I can't help but feel the darkness and tight corridors were there to compensate for the engine limitations, you know like the fog in Silent Hill. Unlike Silent Hill where the fog, combined with the open environment, created an an atmosphere of dread and uneasiness, DOom3's darkness is at first dread inducing  but quickly becomes just plain annoying.The game also cheats. It has a nasty habit of spawning units just out of sight so you think you missed something. And no this isn't the normal teleport with the evil light show. These arr enemies literally just blinking into existence where the designer feels the player will not be looking, like on the other side of a closed door you just came through.THougjh the question to answer is, can I recommend this game. Yes, but do not pick it uop if you're hoping for a good follow-up to the classic Doom games, taken as a generic, sci-fi horror, the game holds up decently, taken as a Doom game, not so much. If you never played the classics, this won't be a bad game for you. Wait for it to go on sale, otherwise I recommend the more recent  installment.

Posted: May 14, 2016
												This game is so lovely.It beats the new Doom 4 game many times over and over again.If you are standing for a choice between buying this, or buying the new Doom 4, buy this instead.(Or better: the BFG edition, then you get more for the bucks)You will enjoy it much more, I promise you.This review applies to Doom 3 and RoE, not the other doom games inside this package.First, you get that nice peaceful playable intro without action that almost every game have today.Such intros always gives you a nice entrypoint (where you come from and why) while it "starts up"the story in a proper way, and also gives a exploration opportunity to learn more about thein-game world without being disturbed by enemies.Then, you get pretty much thinking. You must read PDA's, Emails, listen to audio logs, figure out codes to proceed. Sometimes you need to read Emails or listen to logs to figure out what to do next, for example where specific mission-criticalobjects are stored.And you get no help, you need to figure out platformingfor yourself when that becomes applicable.That makes it extra fun.Another nice thing is that many ingame objects notnecessary for progressing, is also interactive,so sometimes the object is just for fun/enjoyment,sometimes the object is just a red herring to foolyou into thinking this is the next step to take, whenit turns out its not(For example, a door that never can be unlocked,eg requires a PDA or keycard not in game).This interactivity also adds to realism and itmakes the game more fun to play.Also, the really nice thing is that you sometimesreturn to a central "hub" (so theres multiple "hubs")that is specific for the chapter you played, afterhaving collected some keycard/PDA or donesome objective, which makes it extra fun asyou get to revisit old places and take new paths from there. This gives you a more sense of the facility.Also, theres a lot of puzzles that you need to figure out,one notable example is the maintenace elevator/platform,where you are given a slight hint and you have to figurethe rest out itself.And the cryo storage bins puzzle is GREAT. First youthink its just a dead end but after a while you figure it out.And that lovely crane minigame with the toxic leaking barrelswas just beutiful.I could warmly recommend this instead of Doom 4.Put Doom 4 in the garbage bin and buy this instead!

												DOOM 3 may not be scary per say but it definitely is a well-executed form of ACTION survival horror. I prefer the more subtle approach to horror (Silent Hill 2 and 3) but DOOM 3 manages to bring a interesting blend of action and horror thanks to it's crappy feeling guns, dark cramped rooms and bothersome flashlight. The story and characters are forgetable and the DOOM marine has clearly had some therapy compared to his other portrayals. Otherwise it's alright and priced accordingly. DOOM3 is more of an interesting footnote than a great game if you compare it to the legendary DOOM 1 and 2 but it's not too bad in spite of how it's aged when compared to other games like Half-Life 2.

												I didn't like doom 3 when i first played it about 5 years ago so i decided to buy the game on steam and give it another chance to see if my opinion changes. It hasn't.This is one of the most boring games i have ever played and it feels like such a slap in the face to fans of doom 1 and 2 like myself. The shooting feels so clunky, the guns sound weak as hell and combat in general just feels stiff and awful.It's one of the least scary 'horror' games i have ever played and I feel no tension as i'm playing it. The only scare that works is the bathroom mirror scare in the first hour of the game. Unless you are very easily scared this game cannot be called a horror game as it is marketed to be.The enemy design is so uninteresting and boring compared to doom 1 and 2 which had some of the most interesting and memorable enemy design in gaming history its just sad to look at in doom 3.The pacing is awful, you are fighting like 5 ememies at a time max and that's the most tension you will get out of the game is fighting a small bunch of enemies in very tight corridors. The pacing is very slow and boring. If the game didn't have such dull and boring level design and atmosphere maybe the slow pacing would have worked but it just doesn't.I have used the word boring so many times in this review but that's honestly the best way i can describe the game and my experience with it. Boring.3/10 (Bad)

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												Doom 3 is a mixed bag in some cases. On one hand, it manages to be a solid horror game with plenty of scares, scary concepts, and dark spooky rooms. On the other, that just isn't what Doom is. Doom is a fast-paced action game with bunny-hopping, weapon swapping, and non-stop genocidal mayhem. It's about as far from the original Doom as possible in that regard. I personally enjoy the sound design and music, though YMMV. The dark rooms are irritating to some, and while I do agree that the dark rooms themselves are an ordeal, it doesn't feel unintentional. And sure, if you want to completely remove the horror aspect of it then by all means get the BFG edition where you can hold your flashlight and weapon at the same time. But for people who accept it as a horror game, and want to enjoy it as a horror game, and also accept it as a completely different game from Doom, then it is well worth your time. Go check it out.

content:
Posted: January 30
												TLDR at the end!  Doom 3 is probably one of the more disappointing games I've played and it has nothing to do with with its graphics.  The graphics in Doom 3 still look really good today, so thumbs up to Id's workmanship there.WEAPONS:First off, the weapons feel and sound weak in Doom 3.  None of the weapons in Doom 3 sound satisfyhing to fire at all.  They sound almost puny.  For a game that, for the most part, utilizes the other sounds in the game so well, they fall very short on the weapons, except maybe the BFG.  In fact, the weapons are all around just plain weak in this game.  The shotgun is really quite powerful, but only point blank (can 1-shot mid strength monsters).  Since you have to pump the shotty after every shot fired, point blank becomes dangerous and damage drops fast at any range.  You don't really get a powerful weapon until the rocket launcher.  The BFG is only slightly more powerful, which is sad compared to the almighty BFG of past Doom games.  For most of the game the levels are so tightly confined that I didn't even want to use those two unless I was desparate because I could easily kill myself in the process (and did a few times).  The Soul Cube puts the RL and the BFG to shame, but it has firing limitations.  THose limitations border on tedious making the effort it takes working towards the next opportunity to fire it annoying and painful.What I mean by weak.  There is no discernible difference in damage between the pistol, machine gun, chain gun or plasma rifle.  The later 3 just fire faster than pistol.  Using the spider monster in the game as a test, since they come in hordes and it's easy to use them for testing, it took the same number of shots (3) to kill one with any 4 weapons.  If I heard the spiders coming and had some space, I would just pull out the pistol, which has an annoying pause between shots, and pick them off at medium distance.  I'd reserve the other 3 weapons for close quarters, then I would just spray and pray.  This similarity in damage was apparent when used on all monsters.  The chain gun, a detriment to use due to its spin up time.  I usually took more damage with the chain gun than using cover and short bursts with the machine gun or plasma rifle.The grenades are strong, but a pain.  Their game physics treats them like they are those "Super Bounce" rubber balls but without the vertical bounce.  They have almost no vertical arc when thrown (trying to throw it onto a platform above you, or over a crate an enemy is using for cover?  Forget it!) and they bounce and ricochet horizontally all over the place.  Unless it directly hits a monster and explodes, the grenade is likely to ricochet back to you and kill you instead even if thrown around a corner.In the end, it was more effective, in most cases, to learn each monster's melee/fight pattern and just rush in, point blank them with the shotty, then jump out before the mob could recover from it's first missed attack to swing again.  I was even using this tactic on the top 4 of the most powerful monsters in the game outside the 3 bosses.STORY:The story was pretty bad.  Experiments release the hordes of Hell.  You kill the hordes of Hell seeking to take down those responsible and kill them.  Kill the creature holding the door open and close the gate and save Earth.  Good idea.  Doom 1 and 2 did this as well. The problem?  Tons of written dialogue in the form of e-mails.  Tons of voice dialog in the form of audio log files.  Video logs in the form of propaganda. A few cinematics.  Other than a couple minor things in the story, iD used all of this to tell the same story that Doom and Doom 2 told, which both managed to infer without any of the stuff I just mentioned.The only purpose most of that served was to add in probably the dumbest game mechanic ever.  Forcing me to browse every e-mail and audio file just so I can get the combination codes for all the storage compartments holding most of the armor, weapons and ammo.  Initially, it wasn't bad, but it got old quick.  Hello Google!GAMEPLAY:Doom 3 did wrong, what everything a slighlty newer game "Dead Space," did right.  I'm not talking about graphics eventhough Dead Space, graphically, was superior because it's newer.  In Dead Space, every monster that came at you came from somwhere and by that I mean somewhere that makes sense.  They crawled out of panels in bulkheads, from under bridges, holes they "created," busted out of corpses in which it was incubating, or tranformed said corpse into something else for it's own use.  You could hear skittering and crawling all ofer the place. It felt like they could come out at any point from anywhere and it always made sense.  They could be anywhere, anytime, but where-ever they crawled out, it made sense.In Doom 3, many monsters were hidden behind wall panels that were clearly wall panels that, when opened, were just empty closet like rooms where a monster clearly just sat there waiting for it to open.  The "closets" clearly served no purpose other than holding a monster to jack your butt the moment you ran into any small piles are armor/ammo lying around. This caught me off guard the first few times, but then never again.  Many times it was clear a monster just spawned somwhere because you triggered a spot walking through it and "boom" monster smacking you in the back.  No tell-tale sign.  Clearly, the game just popped a monster right behind me.  The only monsters that made sense were the ones that were "summoned" in for lack of a better term and you can hear the teleport sound.  Come on!  This style of monster spawn/use worked for earlier Doom and Quake games, but iD, you guys tried to add a story and go for realism.  Old Doom style monster spawning just doesn't cut it.Dead Space style monster spawning shouldn't be a limitation at the time of Doom 3 and was entirely possible.  Unfortunately, I think iD were still stuck in their Doom (1,2) and Quake (1.2) thinking and failed to bring something new to the table.  Instead Dead Space comes out and blows my socks off, and now I am here wondering how iD couldn't have pulled off something similar a few years earlier.Doom 3 is also too long for what it gives.  I've read from others that it kind of over stays it's welcome and I agree.  You spend forever in industrial style levels that didn't change until I was sent to Hell.  Once in Hell, I thought I was about to reach the end.  NOPE!  I finally end up back on Mars and I think it's close to the end.  NOPE!!  A linear FPS the deilvers task after task to accomplish before reaching the goal.  Many of which leave the game with a bloated "wasting my time busy work" feel.  Hell has the only interesting looking levels in the game although its hard to enjoy them because you can barely see in Hell.  Even with Max brightness.  Hell breaking into reality upon return to Mars looks neat, but only happens in maybe 2 spots.And finally, the most annoying thing about Doom 3.  For much of the game you are pretty ammo starved (even on normal).  This WASN'T a problem.  This was an acceptable thing as it adds some intensity.  The problem was that the moment the game finally ramps up and gives you a plethora of ammo so I can go Bat-Crap crazy, you don't get the chance.  The moment you do, you end up in Hell with no guns or ammo.  You spend most of the Hell regaining it.  Once back to Mars, no guns or ammo.  You spend most of the time rebuilding again.  Most of it adds up to excuses to make the game last a bit longer and feel bloated.  Not Scary at all.TLDR:  GRAPHICS: Still really good even for today.CONTROLS:  Crisp and responsive.WEAPONS: Weak and boring except for Soul Cube. STORY: Useless fluff to tell same story Doom 1 inferred perfectly.GAMEPLAY: Un-inspired, old, bloated style of level progression.  2 horrible game mechanics involving ammo/gun acquisition. Too Long.Sorry, iD.  I love your past games, but sadly this is a thumbs down.

												A sub par, generic FPS with a popular name attached to it with a forgettable story included.Its barely even a DOOM game if your basis for DOOM is 1 or 2.The game can be summed up as a slow, linear plod through corridors as enemies obviously spawn directly infront and behind you over and over and over. content:
Posted: October 21, 2014
												Doom 3.General overview - average.Graphics - 5/10Sounds - 7/10Mechanics - 7/10Storyline - 6/10Time to complete - around 12-16 hours.Prologue of the story - The year is 2145. You are an unknown marine sent to a Mars station to reinforce the troops stationed there. Recently there have been many occupants becoming ill and even dying. On board your flight is a councillor from earth to investigate the recent happenings. You are required to grab your equipment and report for duty. This is where your hellish story begins.This game was released in 2004 and naturally, the graphics look dated. Some aspects are in HD like interactive computer monitors but most of the decals are very pixelated including your weapons which is a shame. The sound is above average with reasonable voice acting but the guns definately needed to sound like they have a heavier punch.There is a variety of weapons from chainsaws, chainguns, rocket launchers, granades and everything in between to put to good use against the enemy. If you search out the nooks and crannies you will find enough ammunition to keep you going. The AI are generally stupid and will persue you except for the marines. Sometimes they take cover.The story is slowly revealed to you through a bunch of PDAs the lab scientists have dropped. Not only do they reveal story plots but some will also have codes to gain access to storage lockers. Another cool aspect was having to go outside the station with a limited oxygen supply. It gives a real sense of dread of suffication. To add to the suspense you must lower your weapon to use a flash light. Some will find this a nuisanse if they just want a plain run and gun game.Conclusion : Don't expect epic content from this game but if you'd like to take a crack at a classic then this would definately count. Other notes : I had problems choosing a higher resolution to play the game in. It would always crash when I chose which one I wanted. Please check the guides for a work around to get better resolutions. It involves typing commands into the console. Unfortunately you have to do this everytime you open the game. I have a G15 keyboard so I bound the commands to one of my macro keys. Minimised the annoyance.

After an hour of playing nothing surprised me, because I knew that every blind corner or locked door held a "surprise" enemy in it. The most linear and BORING maps I have ever seen. I mean look at System Shock 2 from the freakin 90s! That entire game takes place on an industrial style space ship, which is a very similar environment to Doom 3, but each level is uniqe with a different design and feel. All of the hallways in Doom 3 are identical.Finally, one of the most annoying aspects of this game was the sound of the guns. Why do all the guns sound like toys?! The shotgun sound sounds like a bb gun; it's idiotic. After 7 hours of playing I looked online and saw a lot of people saying that it got better in the Hell levels, so I looked up a guide and the hell levels are only the last quarter of the game! Any game that takes more than 2 hours to get "good" is a game that belongs in the garbage. Doom 1 and 2 are roling in their graves and this piece of trash does not deserve to be called by the same name. I loved Doom 1 and 2 and I drink to their memory while I p155 on Doom 3's grave.

												I decided to play this game quite a while ago because it was on sale and I was like "Why not?"Let me tell you, this game blows. It is fun for about an hour and then it just goes stale. The game is totally repetive, in the sense that the only activity you do is combat. "Oh look, demon #53. Click. Dead. Oh look, demon #54. Click. Dead."You might say "Wait, that sounds like all shooter games!" No, that isn't true. Good shooters have a variety of weapons where each fits a different and essential role in combat. In DOOM 3, there are weapons that suck and are never used, and OP god-like weapons. Good shooters have a few abilities or combat tricks that you can use to react to enemies. In DOOM 3, the only move is click and shoot. DOOM 3 is also way to hard. Enemies spawn literally right behind you or next to you, then immediately use moves that you have no chance to avoid and/or one-hit-kill the player. Perhaps the worst thing is the complete lack of narrative. Only once did the game break into cutscene or feature some kind of dialouge. Basically, the plot is "For some reason that nobody ever finds out, a hell portal opens randomly in some mars facility. Now go kill demons non-stop for 10 hours and then you win."DOOM 3 is the worst shooter I've ever played. Utter garbage.

Sikkmod makes this game look better than the BFG edition, and other mods such as the LMS 4.0 (Wave survival, Custom coop) and OpenCoop (campaign and custom coop) provide extreme replayability. A ton of custom single player modded maps are also available for your choosing, most notably Tested and the Ultimate Hell Campaign. At $12 for the doom 3 + ROE pack, this is a steal, and even more so during steam sales.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
												When I first played Doom 3 I thought it was just so-so; a shooter that controlled well with a nice engine and cool lighting, but not a Doom game. I've grown to change my mind, and in fact this has become one of my very favourite games. I've played this thing over and over and over and it gets better every single time.id's engine is nothing short of miraculous. The level design is tight (though sometimes unremarkable and confusing) and the player can hide behind, jump on, and squeeze through everything you'd expect. The use of shadow in the design is superior to any other game, and having to juggle between a gun and a flashlight, even though it's ridiculous, adds tension and fun.The monsters are a loving homage to the original games. The animations are incredible and become spookier every time I upgrade my PC (especially with my 144hz monitor - it's SO fluid). They're fun to fight and id kept the important mechanic of having the player run faster than any other enemy, making movement your most effective weapon. That's the key ingredient of Doom and that's what makes Doom 3 a true sequel.It's fun to navigate, it's fun to shoot, and every moment is full of tension and wonder as you explore. Doom 3 is a gem and I can confidently call it a "desert island game". I never seem to get tired of it.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												DOOM 3 flawlessly creates an immersive survival horror fps, which is great fun to play through and explore. The game is genuinely challenging on harder difficulties, including Nightmare mode, and features excellent gunplay. Sound design is masterful, as well as the game's artistic style. Everything looks and sounds right in every situation. The aesthetic of Hell in particular is particularly unnerving, you can tell that the guys who made this had a good time imaging creepy stuff. All the guns from DOOM return, from the lowly pistol, all the way up to the devastating BFG 9000. Another of the game's strong points is that every gun, including the aformentioned pistol, feels powerful. The monsters also return, with a few new ones, and have been given (at the time) modern facelifts. Imps are just as annoying as ever, and Hell Knights are particularly terrifying. The game is also jam packed with lore and collectable goodies to discover. Read the PDAs of your fallen comrades to reveal personal emails and voice recordings which tell you everything about the situation, as well as other funny situations they may have been in. All in all, DOOM 3 provides a memorable horror FPS experience which, despite its age, holds up well to this day. If you don't own this, get it, whether it's on sale or not.

												Doom 3 is a simple shooter, though I mean that as a compliment. It's classic non-stop action, never overly complicated, but not incredibly clever. It has style though, and isn't always easy. The creepy atmosphere doesn't last long, once you realize there's nothing but jump scares waiting around every health pack. The game starts to drag near the end, but it's strange to argue that a game has too much, In truth, the length of the game hurts the roller coaster nature of the action. Is Doom 3 a classic? Hard to say, but it felt like one while I was playing it, even if I wasn't sure at the end.

												For me to call doom 3 a traditional doom game would be a flat out lie. It lacks mostly everything that made the doom games so great, levels are much more linear (still not as bad as many modern shooter) and it's less of a frantic fast paced action game and more of a slow, atmospheric horror game. There's nothing wrong with the latter of course, it's just a different approach to the series. The gunplay is solid thought there's nothing exceptional, the weapons are taken from the orginial doom, with a couple exceptions, such as the interesting soul cube. Monsters are taken from classic doom as well, which is great. It's quite a sight to see how monsters such as the cacodemon and mancubus translated into the Tech 4 Engine. The issue is the most iconic monster, the "pinky" demon is so grossly underused. I think I counted maybe 8 in the entire game? However, my biggest complain with the game is the lack of variety in the levels. The entire games takes place on a base on mars, which = boring.

												When I first played Doom 3 I thought it was just so-so; a shooter that controlled well with a nice engine and cool lighting, but not a Doom game. I've grown to change my mind, and in fact this has become one of my very favourite games. I've played this thing over and over and over and it gets better every single time.id's engine is nothing short of miraculous. The level design is tight (though sometimes unremarkable and confusing) and the player can hide behind, jump on, and squeeze through everything you'd expect. The use of shadow in the design is superior to any other game, and having to juggle between a gun and a flashlight, even though it's ridiculous, adds tension and fun.The monsters are a loving homage to the original games. The animations are incredible and become spookier every time I upgrade my PC (especially with my 144hz monitor - it's SO fluid). They're fun to fight and id kept the important mechanic of having the player run faster than any other enemy, making movement your most effective weapon. That's the key ingredient of Doom and that's what makes Doom 3 a true sequel.It's fun to navigate, it's fun to shoot, and every moment is full of tension and wonder as you explore. Doom 3 is a gem and I can confidently call it a "desert island game". I never seem to get tired of it.

												In the beginning, there is a slight problem with the graphics.  THIS CAN BE TAKEN CARE OF BY:Ctrl+Alt+~and entering the commands: /*r_customwidth [Enter Your Computer's Width]            //(Ex:  1920)r_customheight [Enter Your Computer's Height]          //(Ex: 1080)r_mode -1r_aspectratio 1           // (16:9 Aspect Ratio, Standard Widescreen Definition)image_anisotrophy 8  // (I believe this is antialiasing?)vid_restart                 // (restarts video screen)*/ALTERNATIVE METHOD:  USING THE FOLDER PATHWAY TO DOOMLocate DoomConfig.cfg file using the folders:C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\SteamApps\common\Doom 3\baseLocate: seta r_customWidth "[Enter Your Computer's Width]"       seta r_customHeight "[Enter Your Computer's Height]"        seta r_mode "-1"      seta image_anisotropy "8"      Then save the file and open Doom 3 in steam.Now you can enjoy Doom in HD.REVIEW: Doom 3 is a very fun game.  The map is completely different than most as you are stationed on a super massive civilization sized building on mars with lots of rooms and hallways.  Tight corners, darkness, excitement, and lots of shoot em up action.  Enemy spawns are very close and due to tight corners, lots of enemies can spawn at once.  Ammo is scarce and it is very dark.  This all adds to the classic Doom experience.  Enemies are very diverse and mobilize in many different formations.My favorite enemy were the imps who slung explosive balls of sludge that would explode in a spectacular nova on contact with a surface.  This combined with their charge and talon slashing made them a very awing enemy to fight. They were especially fun in the dark when the explosions would light up the metal rooms in a pleasant orange glow.  My least favorite enemy was the cacodemon.  Its basic health pool and slow movement speed made them easy targets with only one ability to launch a lethal cannon shot.  The wraith teleporters were also very cool.  Imp and wraith swarms were the best mobs to go up against.  The rapid succession of rushes and teleports added an element of adrenaline to the fight. Some areas of the game were composed of a few large enemies contained in a small space.   The demon and hell knights for example took up large areas and made it hard to navigate as they took advantage of their larger unit sizes.  Trites would surround and immobilize you as well proving to be annoying.  Arch Viles felt very foreign.  They exhibited some very unique characteristics such as being able to learn where your gun was pointed and react.  Camping at the end of a hallway with a pillar to use for cover as the enemies funneled in would work on most, but the Arch Viles would always do something chaotic.  The commando unit was very agressive and well equipped.  I was never left unscathed by them.  Cherubs along with trites would overwhelm and surround you.   When first introduced to revenants, they were difficult, but as the game progressed their abilities did not scale well.  Their movement speed was slow and rockets predictable.  They were most dangerous in the tight hallways and corridors of the main levels inside the mars base.  Combat was a rich and enjoyable experience, but the platform parts of the game and puzzles were challenging for me.  I did not like having to read the PDA documents to find secret codes to open doors.  Some parts of the game had you jump from platform to platform to reach the next area.  These were difficult and resulted in many deaths.  I did not learn of the f5 save option until after beating the hell level.  Much time was burned rinsing and repeating the process of trying to get across the platforms and attempting to solve the puzzles without use of the save.  My own ignorance resulted in lots of time grinding through the levels.  It was all part of the experience.Rating 8.5/10

												10/10 I played through Doom 3 on the original XBOX (way after it came out) and I immediately knew that this was going to be something I would enjoy. However, they get fairly predictable.-The two coolest levels in the game are just that: Only two levels.-Doesn't always play like Doom (But it doesn't have to, necessarily) Overall, this is a really good game that sold around 3.5 Million copies, and any PC owner should have this in their library. I've played around 4 playthroughs of this and it's expansion, Resurrection of Evil.

I found it to keep true to classic Doom in a lot of ways - you'll find a lot of the same enemies and items, and of course the scary feel is there as well, as anything could jump out at you at any time. The creepiness is helped by a great build-up at the start. It's a good balance between scary and action, though. Throughout the game you will make use of a PDA which is a clever way of keeping track of security keys, which will give you access to secrets and new areas, while also giving you some comical background about life on the station before the whole demonic invasion thing.

It took atmosphere, graphics, and sound design to a whole new level, and the game STILL looks stunning TO THIS DAY.The gameplay is fun and frantic and harkens back to the old-school days of FPS, which in this day and age is a blessing.Again, ahead of it's time and a trailblazer, nearly everything you find in Dead Space (and many other games) was created or perfected in this game like in-game PDAs, flashlights in the dark, electronic readouts over doors and guns, etc. If it didn't create some of these things, it was popularized with this game.Though System Shock and a few others before had treaded very similar ground, Doom 3 took things to a whole new level.Play in the dark with the sound up and have a hell of a time.

Posted: July 16, 2014
												Doom 3 is a decent game, though it has many problems.The opening sections have an atmosphere that is unparalleled, and there are intermittent scenes that are also great. That said, partway through the game it becomes a much more generic game that lapses in its scariness. If you take away the darkness and you hold down the run key, the game is basically the same run and gun shooters its predecessors were in many sections. If you were a huge fan of the first games and this is what you like, then that's great. If you're looking for something deeper than that, then you may have to try harder to immerse yourself. As I said, the beginning definitely is everything it is advertised to be. Later in the game, though, I found myself getting very bored and hoping the game would end.Most of the enemies just jump toward you and are designed to fluster you. It's not really scary for the most part, but if you are easily scared as I was as a young teenager playing this game, it will freak you out. It becomes predictable as well. Enemies spawn in most rooms, you gun them down, then you repeat in the next room. The formula works out for a while, but by the time you get to, say, the Delta Labs, you'll be wishing the game would throw something new at you. The boss fights are exciting decent but easy, perhaps with the exception of the Cyberdemon that appears in every Doom game ever. Many people complain about not being able to use the flashlight and shoot at the same time. While it can be annoying at first, once you get good at switching it actually works pretty well. I know the new BFG edition allows you to use both, but I feel like that would kill the experience too much. It adds a new level of strategy and horror, so don't be too put off by it.There's not much of a storyline, but there really doesn't need to be. You're just trying to survive and make it through the Mars base, eventually defeating the demonic forces, while hitting a number of objectives along the way.The graphics are good, about what you'd expect from a game made back in 2003. The facial animations are terrible (except for the player's own and a few notable other NPCs), but the rest is decent. The mirrors actually work though! This is something most developers try to avoid, but id Software did them right!I would definitely recommend this game to people wanting a decent horror experience, but I warn that it will get repetitive about halfway through the game. If you can look past that, it is a very fun horror shooting experience!

												Welcome to the mess hall, marine. Powered by one of the greatest game engines as a perfect exhibit for all of its astonishing capabilities, DOOM 3 packs a weighty punch. The highly interactive environments, the seamless integration with the PDA, and the splendid lighting create an atmosphere that is a living, breathing entity, urging all players to explore every corner, discover rewarding secrets and delve into its intriguing history. The sound effects deserve a special mention; from firing the shotgun or reloading a plasma gun, to the whirring machinery and hideous cries of the demon horde, not a single note is wasted, adding another layer of quality to the experience. Of course the action is outstanding, this is id software after all, the weapons and enemy variety are second to none. One substantial complaint is directed at the final boss battle, an anticlimactic disappointment that is way too easy, especially considering all of the preceding fights that led up to it. The hell level is short-lived and the true evil of the setting is never completely embraced, which is rather discouraging, and not something anyone wants from a DOOM game no less. Even with these faults it is still one of the best FPS games available and for damn good reason; id software created the genre.DOOM 3 is another exquisite chapter of a dearly beloved series that will have you hooked from the second you press New Game.9/10

content:
Posted: October 25, 2016
												Returning to DOOM 3 after twelve (!) years of other first person shooters is simultaneously refreshing and frustrating.Pacing is generally fantastic, and the game is still oh so atmospheric. Audio logs are fantastically voiced, the environmental storytelling is great, generally speaking it does a fantastic job at creating the impression of a real working facility full of scared and frustrated workers. The dark industrial sci-fi theme is well realised and consistent, everything fits together nicely and the demon designs are my favourite of the series. Though I will admit they look more alienish than demonic, I still think they fit well for this particular game.DOOM 3 is from a time before mission markers, so if you're not careful you can easily get lost. I found I adjusted fairly quickly to this, and became better at overcoming obstacles without guidance after a few hours. It can be frustrating, but the lack of any assistance does enhance the feeling of isolation and claustraphobia, and gives the game a nice survival horror esq aftertaste. Exploration feels more natural because of the lack of hand-holding, in my opinion. It's not nearly as bad as DOOM II, which had me searching for hours on some levels for that last bloody switch.Some of DOOM 3 hasn't aged well, though, in my opinion. There's a distinct lack of agility in the player character, you'll rarely be able to dodge enemy attacks up close even by dashing backwards or to the sides. This can leave combat feeling like attrition, more a numbers game than a test of skill. Especially when you factor in DOOM 3's love of monster closets and spawning enemies behind you. The oppressive darkness doesn't help, it's literally pitch black in places which makes picking out targets an utter ballache. You can switch to the flashlight, but most of the time you'll be shooting one enemy whilst another approaches in total darkness from his flank.Overall, though, I think DOOM 3 still does more right than wrong. It feels a little conflicted at times, like it's unsure whether it wants to be a horror game or an action game, but I think it does both well enough to be consistently enteraining. It's like a time capsule, the embodiment of design sentiments from a time before Halo and Call of Duty really changed the scene.

												Let me get this straight - this game is not downright bad, but it's not a lot of fun either. Read on for more info.A departure from the series' roots, the third DOOM makes itself into an atmospheric game, much like Metro. However, unlike Metro this game is not a lot of fun to play.The best thing by far is the re-imaginations of the monsters, weapons and other entities from the original games. The climate comes just behind. Unfortunately, the combat is possibly the weakest point.As I said in my joke-review the gameplay is about walking down maze-like corridors and stopping every few seconds to deal with an ambush. That would have been somewhat alright if not for the fact that a lot of these sections are identical. There are very few areas in the game which try to mix things up a bit. The weapons feel clumsy and cumbersome just like the movement, which doesn't help.The only thing that justifies buying this game is the last third, which shakes up the level design of metallic corridors with hellish growth and lava. Enemies appear in groups of bigger than 2 at a time and from different angles. I sincerely enjoyed that part, but leading up to it felt tedious and I wouldn't want to do it again. Also, mods.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2016
												Returning to DOOM 3 after twelve (!) years of other first person shooters is simultaneously refreshing and frustrating.Pacing is generally fantastic, and the game is still oh so atmospheric. Audio logs are fantastically voiced, the environmental storytelling is great, generally speaking it does a fantastic job at creating the impression of a real working facility full of scared and frustrated workers. The dark industrial sci-fi theme is well realised and consistent, everything fits together nicely and the demon designs are my favourite of the series. Though I will admit they look more alienish than demonic, I still think they fit well for this particular game.DOOM 3 is from a time before mission markers, so if you're not careful you can easily get lost. I found I adjusted fairly quickly to this, and became better at overcoming obstacles without guidance after a few hours. It can be frustrating, but the lack of any assistance does enhance the feeling of isolation and claustraphobia, and gives the game a nice survival horror esq aftertaste. Exploration feels more natural because of the lack of hand-holding, in my opinion. It's not nearly as bad as DOOM II, which had me searching for hours on some levels for that last bloody switch.Some of DOOM 3 hasn't aged well, though, in my opinion. There's a distinct lack of agility in the player character, you'll rarely be able to dodge enemy attacks up close even by dashing backwards or to the sides. This can leave combat feeling like attrition, more a numbers game than a test of skill. Especially when you factor in DOOM 3's love of monster closets and spawning enemies behind you. The oppressive darkness doesn't help, it's literally pitch black in places which makes picking out targets an utter ballache. You can switch to the flashlight, but most of the time you'll be shooting one enemy whilst another approaches in total darkness from his flank.Overall, though, I think DOOM 3 still does more right than wrong. It feels a little conflicted at times, like it's unsure whether it wants to be a horror game or an action game, but I think it does both well enough to be consistently enteraining. It's like a time capsule, the embodiment of design sentiments from a time before Halo and Call of Duty really changed the scene.
