content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
												Welcome to the mess hall, marine. Powered by one of the greatest game engines as a perfect exhibit for all of its astonishing capabilities, DOOM 3 packs a weighty punch. The highly interactive environments, the seamless integration with the PDA, and the splendid lighting create an atmosphere that is a living, breathing entity, urging all players to explore every corner, discover rewarding secrets and delve into its intriguing history. The sound effects deserve a special mention; from firing the shotgun or reloading a plasma gun, to the whirring machinery and hideous cries of the demon horde, not a single note is wasted, adding another layer of quality to the experience. Of course the action is outstanding, this is id software after all, the weapons and enemy variety are second to none. One substantial complaint is directed at the final boss battle, an anticlimactic disappointment that is way too easy, especially considering all of the preceding fights that led up to it. The hell level is short-lived and the true evil of the setting is never completely embraced, which is rather discouraging, and not something anyone wants from a DOOM game no less. Even with these faults it is still one of the best FPS games available and for damn good reason; id software created the genre.DOOM 3 is another exquisite chapter of a dearly beloved series that will have you hooked from the second you press New Game.9/10

Posted: March 14, 2016
												Let me get this straight - this game is not downright bad, but it's not a lot of fun either. Read on for more info.A departure from the series' roots, the third DOOM makes itself into an atmospheric game, much like Metro. However, unlike Metro this game is not a lot of fun to play.The best thing by far is the re-imaginations of the monsters, weapons and other entities from the original games. The climate comes just behind. Unfortunately, the combat is possibly the weakest point.As I said in my joke-review the gameplay is about walking down maze-like corridors and stopping every few seconds to deal with an ambush. That would have been somewhat alright if not for the fact that a lot of these sections are identical. There are very few areas in the game which try to mix things up a bit. The weapons feel clumsy and cumbersome just like the movement, which doesn't help.The only thing that justifies buying this game is the last third, which shakes up the level design of metallic corridors with hellish growth and lava. Enemies appear in groups of bigger than 2 at a time and from different angles. I sincerely enjoyed that part, but leading up to it felt tedious and I wouldn't want to do it again. Also, mods.

												They really don't make shooters like they used to anymore. While the latest shooters are more focused on graphics and online multiplayer, Doom 3 focused more on story, environment, and the core gunplay. Every environment is carefully thought out, the appearance of new enemies always makes you wonder what will come next, and the guns are all fun to use, once you get the hang of them. Above all, because this game was made more than 10 years ago, it runs fantastically on my otherwise sub-par computer, averaging more than twice the normal FPS I play at. What's more, the game is, as far as I can tell, free of bugs and glitches (Although don't expect to get into the martianbuddy lockers. There's only 2, though).

												Doom 3 in comparison to Doom 2, is quite terminal and lacks a lot of the features of gameplay required to appropriate it as a Doom title. Regardless of this fact, despite being a "negative review" you should judge my review on the basis of being a  Doom  game not a standalone or a spin-off. Basically put, as any FPS it's good but as Doom it's poor.It considerably lacks the movement speed seen in Doom 1 and 2 with Run enabled, the game takes place mainly indoors and on Mars, not once allowing the player to experience the same level of immersion given to Doom 2 until you reach Hell. Quite lacking in the department of edge that gave the game that level of "You're in Hell forever" and it's metalhead atmosphere, felt far more scripted and bit too grimdark for my tastes. Felt more like playing System Shock with Doom Weapons but without the same level of depth as System Shock or Doom itself. It feels like the ID team were attempting to make an intelligent and fun shooter but lacked either, meaning development time was short to implement the right mix of concepts.As a standalone, the sequel to ID's famed shooter,  DooM. The IDTech engine has been upgraded graphically supporting some very impressive visuals for it's time and sikkmod immeasurably improves the visuals to such a photorealistic degree, it's quite revolutionary. Doom 3 does improve greatly on the survival horror aspect of the genre through directed narrative of a teleportation technology gone terribly wrong (prepare for foreseen consequences), lacking significant ammo for weapons, using sound effects in the dark to ominously warn players and using darkness as a way to surprise the players and the generally satisfactory level design and great lighting help aid it. Expect to cack your pants often from a Demon Imp coming out of no where and scratching you to bits if you do purchase it.

												Doom 3: It's what I always considered to be the low point in the franchise. Relatively speaking of course, because it's still a fun game, but it isn't a "masterpiece" like some people will rave on about. It's got it's fair share of issues that prevent it from achieving that status like it's predecessors, and Doom 2016 in many ways is the game that Doom 3 should have been.  And before you go look at "professional" reviews, I already did. It's more proof that they have almost no idea as to what they are talking about.First off it's a much slower game than the rest.  Your movement speed is dramatically decreased from the older games, reloading is a concern, you have a limited sprint, and it has a much stronger horror element to it than the older games did. It's still a game about exorsizing  hell with hot lead, but it's less frantic than the other games, and tries to be scary. Sure, people like to blab on about "atmosphere, crepiness, blah BLAH BLAH", but in reality it comes off more cheesy than anything else. Perhaps I've been desensitized to that sort of thing over the years,but even when I first played the game at 15 I thought it was only occasionally mildly discomforting.  That's not a negative, as I like cheesy movies and games, but don't expect anything freaky.One thing I noticed playing 6 years later that people don't tell you, is that the game has a amazingly cheap tactic of frequently spawning monsters in behind and in front of you at the same time. If it happened on occasion it wouldn't be so bad, but  85% of the time when you see a monster you need to check behind you or you wind up gettingâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥in the rear while you are busy fighting whatever is in front of you.  It's annoying I still recommend the game, because it is a fun and enjoyable experience. It's still an old school shooter at it's core and it might not be the best sequel, but it is still a game for those of us that prefer strafing and keycard hunting, instead of qte',xp  and screaming 13 year olds.
